prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext:
The power to transfer under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 is broader than the power of individual courts in certain respects.
The concept of transfer under this statute is not limited to the traditional views of venue.[
1] The Panel can transfer cases for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings to districts in which venue could not properly be laid initially[2] or to courts that cannot exercise jurisdiction over some of the defendants.[
3] The power to transfer cases for efficient case management under § 1407 trumps exclusive venue provisions in other statutes.
For example, although the statute governing federal crop insurance claims provides that actions under the statute may be brought only in the district where the farm is located,[4] the Panel has ordered that it can transfer such actions to any district, just as it does other actions.[
5]

The Panel can order transfer of entire actions, including the claims against defendants who have not been served.[
6] The Panel has noted, however, that special considerations come into play when questions of transfer of actions against defendants who have not been served are before it.
In one early decision the Panel stated:

When defendants named in a particular case have not been served or notified and have therefore not had the opportunity to object to a proposed transfer, the Panel may not be able to conclude that the § 1407 standard is satisfied, even though the case may appear to meet the statutory criteria for transfer.
Factors which may be significant in determining the propriety of transferring such cases include: (1) the strength of the showing that transfer is desirable, (2) the presence or absence of plaintiff's good faith in naming the unserved defendants, (3) the extent of plaintiff's effort to serve each defendant with process, (4) the degree to which the unserved defendant's interests appear to be the same as those of the defendants coming before the Panel, (5) the number of unserved defendants, and (6) the importance of their presence before the Panel in aiding its decision.
[7]

Although the statute speaks of actions pending in different “districts,” the Panel has suggested in one case that it may have the power to transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings cases pending before the United States Court of Claims.[
8] It did not reach the issue in that case, but, rather, deferred to voluntary coordination between the transferee court and the Court of Claims.[
9] It is probable that the Panel would transfer such cases in a situation where voluntary coordination would not be likely to succeed.

The power to transfer under § 1407 is frequently said to be broader than the power to transfer for venue purposes.
In truth, the Panel's power of transfer is definitely different from that of a district judge deciding a question of venue, but it is both broader in scope and more narrowly defined.
The Panel's decision is largely a matter of discretion, and it is not subject to any appellate review.[
10]

The three most important powers of the Panel relating to transfer that are not involved in venue decisions are the ability to transfer to a district where the court could not exercise personal jurisdiction, power to transfer where venue does not lie, and the power to transfer portions of actions.
These powers have been frequently relied on by the Panel in considering transfer motions.

The Panel has frequently stated that the power of transfer is broader than that encompassed by considerations of venue.[
11] The Panel can order transfer of actions to a court that would not otherwise have subject-matter jurisdiction,[ 12] where venue does not otherwise lie,[13] and can do so before the defendants to be affected by the transfer have been served with process.[
14]

The Panel's most detailed discussion of its power to transfer beyond the mere considerations of venue arose in a series of cases involving national banks.
In these cases, primarily securities cases, national banks were made parties.
Under a special venue statute existing at the time,[15] national banks could only be sued in the district encompassing the county of their home office.
This statute had been rigorously enforced in both the state and federal courts.[
16] The Panel quickly determined that this statute did not prevent it from transferring litigation involving national banks to a different district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.[
17] The Panel articulated its reasons for transferring actions against national banks to distant districts when appropriate:

[The banks] stress that 12 U.S.C. § 94 was enacted for the convenience of the national banks to protect them from having to move their records outside their home districts.
This policy of the Act, they assert, as discussed in the recent United States Supreme Court case of Radzanower v. Touche Ross & Co., 426 U.S. 148, 96 S. Ct. 1989, 48 L. Ed. 2d 540 (1976), would be violated by transferring the actions against the banks for pretrial purposes.
Though the national banks realize that transfers under Section 1407 are not restricted by considerations of venue, they urge the Panel to give deference to the policy behind the venue provision of the National Bank Act by denying transfer.

We see no reason, including anything in Radzanower, to exempt actions involving national banks from transfer under Section 1407.
In considering transfer under Section 1407 the Panel is not encumbered by considerations of venue, including those under 12 U.S.C. § 94.
The fact that defendants may not all be amenable to suit in the same jurisdiction does not prevent transfer of the actions against them to a single district for pretrial proceedings where the prerequisites of Section 1407 are otherwise satisfied.
Indeed, 28 U.S.C. § 1407(a) states that‘actions may be transferred to any district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.’
The legislative history of Section 1407 is also instructive on this point ….

Furthermore, we see no reason to accord national banks any special treatment in considering transfer of actions under Section 1407.
The Panel's statutory mandate is to weigh the interests of all the plaintiffs and all the defendants, and to consider multidistrict litigation as a whole in light of the purpose of the law.

We emphasize that defendant national banks need not worry about a transferee court's entering an order requiring that their documents be moved outside their home districts for trial because transfers under Section 1407 are for pretrial only and the actions against them will be remanded to their home districts for trial.
Moreover, we note that transfer under Section 1407 does not mean that all discovery must take place in the transferee district.
[18]
Although the special venue provision favoring national banks is no longer on the books,[19] the debate over how it affected the Panel is instructive on the scope of the Panel's powers.

Unlike a court considering a motion for change of venue, the Panel does not need to transfer an entire action if it orders transfer.
The statute provides for separation of any claim and remand of it to the transferor court at the time transfer is ordered.[
20] The Panel has frequently used this power to transfer related actions and claims and to leave unrelated claims for separate treatment in the districts where they were filed[21] Primary claims may be transferred while counterclaims may be remanded.
Similarly, a single counterclaim may be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with other cases while the balance of the claims, counterclaims, and crossclaims in the action are remanded for proceedings in the transferor court.
This power is directly related to the Panel's role in increasing the efficiency with which the federal courts manage litigation.
Where claims will not benefit from transfer, or where the burdens of transfer will exceed the benefits to be derived from transfer, transfer will not be ordered.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
In re Peanut Crop Ins. Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1353, 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Great Western Ranches Litigation, 369 F. Supp. 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
See, e.g., Matter of New York City Mun. Securities Litigation, 572 F.2d 49, 51 (2d Cir. 1978).

See In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation, 399 F. Supp. 1397 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Highway Acc. Near Rockville, Connecticut, on December 30, 1972, 388 F. Supp. 574 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Truck Acc. Near Alamagordo, New Mexico, on June 18, 1969, 387 F. Supp. 732 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
The Panel has noted, however, that the ability of a court to exercise personal jurisdiction over the defendants is a factor that it will consider in deciding transfer decisions.
See In re Air Crash Disaster Near Hanover, N. H., 314 F. Supp. 62, 63 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
Although this may not be a directly valid consideration of’ the Panel, the decision may recognize that additional actions may be filed, and that by transferring the action to a district where the court can exercise jurisdiction over all the potential defendants the Panel can obviate tag-along motions since the new actions could be initially filed in the transferee district.
The role of jurisdiction in selection of a transferee district is discussed in § 6:20.
In re Peanut Crop Ins. Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1353, 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
See In re Gypsum Wallboard, 302 F. Supp. 794 (J.P.M.L. 1969); In re Library Editions of Children's Books, 299 F. Supp. 1139, 1141 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
See In re Library Editions of Children's Books, 299 F. Supp. 1139, 1143 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
See In re Western Elec. Co. Semiconductor Patent Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 378, 380 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
Appellate review of transfer decisions by the Panel is discussed in § 11:1.

See, e.g., Matter of New York City Mun. Securities Litigation, 572 F.2d 49, 51 (2d Cir. 1978).
See also In re Falstaff Brewing Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1225, 1229 (J.P.M.L. 1977).

The Panel has historically deferred to the transferee court for consideration and decision of questions relating to jurisdiction.
See, e.g., In re Colocotronis Tanker Securities Litigation, 420 F. Supp. 998 (J.P.M.L. 1976).

See, e.g., In re Falstaff Brewing Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1225, 1229 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
The transferor court must have subject-matter jurisdiction, however.
See BancOhio Corp. v. Fox, 516 F.2d 29, 32 (6th Cir. 1975).
If the action was not properly brought in the federal court for the reason that there is no subject-matter jurisdiction, dismissal is appropriate.
Dismissal on this ground can be ordered by the transferee court if transfer is ordered by the Panel.
The power of the transferee court to consider motions, including motions to dismiss, is discussed in §§ 9:13 and 9:20.

See In re Library Editions of Children's Books, 299 F. Supp. 1139, 1143 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
The Panel recognizes the right of unserved defendants to be heard on the transfer question after they have been served.
See generally 15 Charles Alan Wright, Arthur R. Miller & Edward H. Cooper, Federal Practice and Procedure § 3813, at 81 (4th ed. 2013).

See, e.g., In re Westec Corp., 307 F. Supp. 559, 562 n.8 (J.P.M.L. 1969); see also Matter of New York City Mun. Securities Litigation, 572 F.2d 49, 51 (2d Cir. 1978); In re Falstaff Brewing Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1225, 1229 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Investors Funding Corp. of New York Securities Litigation, 437 F. Supp. 1199, 1202–03 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Multidistrict Litigation Involving Banking Agreements with Stirling Homex Corp., 388 F. Supp. 572, 573 n.1 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Great Western Ranches Litigation, 369 F. Supp. 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
In re Falstaff Brewing Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1225, 1229 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
See 12 U.S.C.A. § 94.

See 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407(a).
The statute is reproduced in § 3:19, below.
Separation of claims is discussed in detail in §§ 5:57 to 5:59.
